S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: Comparison of federated learning systems with secure aggregation. “L”ightweight cryptography.“R”esilience against drop-out clients so that secure aggregation can still be correctly accomplished. “K”eys kept secret in handling dropouts so that drop-out clients’ secret keys are not exposed. “S”ecurity for computation integrity against the server. “C”ompression and security co-design for high communication efficiency while ensuring security. “I”ndividual keys without TTP.

references:
In an independent work, Mandal et al. [17] consider a special scenario where they hide the model from the clients and rely on homomorphic encryption to build specific federated linear/logistic regression models.
Our system follows most prior works with focus on protecting individual model updates and is general for training any models.
We note that some previous works [4, 3] also integrate orthogonal differential privacy techniques by adding calibrated noises to local model updates and lead to an inherent trade-off on accuracy and privacy with delicate parameter tuning, which is complementary to our system.
Table I summarizes the comparison with the most related works discussed above.

references:
Each round proceeds through the following steps: (1) A fraction of the data owners (say K𝐾K data owners) is selected by the server and a current global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is sent to these data owners.
(2) Each selected data owner then performs training over its local dataset, for which any optimizers could be used, though stochastic gradient descent (SGD) is the most popular one.
With SGD, the k𝑘k-th selected data owner updates the local model parameters via 𝐰k←𝐰−η⋅∇L​(𝐰;β)←subscript𝐰𝑘𝐰⋅𝜂∇𝐿𝐰𝛽\mathbf{w}_{k}\leftarrow\mathbf{w}-\eta\cdot\nabla L(\mathbf{w};\beta), where β𝛽\beta is a batch randomly sampled from the local dataset and η𝜂\eta is the learning rate.
A full iteration over the whole local dataset is referred to as an epoch, and the local training could be performed over multiple epochs.
(3) Once the local training is done, an individual model update 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k} is shared for aggregation: 𝐰=1K​∑k=1K𝐰k𝐰1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑘1subscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}=\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits^{K}_{k=1}{\mathbf{w}_{k}}, which produces an updated global model for next round.
In Table II, we provide a summary of the main notations used in this paper.

S8.T3.caption: TABLE III: Size of Model Updates (in MB)
S8.T3.table:
Setting MNIST CIFAR CelebA
Plaintext FL 0.083 88.78 53.26
Sec. FL (scaling) 0.083 88.78 53.26
Sec. FL (16-bit quantization) 0.042 44.49 26.63
Sec. FL (8-bit quantization) 0.021 22.19 13.32
references:
In Table III, we report the size of a model update (i.e., sizes of model update parameters), for the plaintext case and our secure design under the settings of scaling, 8-bit quantization, and 16-bit quantization, respectively.
Our secure protocol with scaling incurs no overhead on the model update size, as the bit precision remains the same.
Our secure protocol can achieve 4×4\times reduction under 8-bit quantization and 2×2\times reduction under 16-bit quantization on the size of transferred model update in a round.
Recall that our system exhibits similar behavior in accuracy evolution with regard to varying number of rounds.
Given a target number of rounds, our system with quantization can lead to 2×2\times or 4×4\times reduction on the communication, with comparable accuracy to the plaintext baseline.

S8.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Performance Complexity Comparison
references:
We now make comparison with the most related prior work [7] without heavy cryptographic operations.
Firstly, we compare the computational complexity on the client side and on the cloud server side respectively.
Suppose the dimension of each model update vector is m𝑚m, and the number of clients being selected in a round of the federated learning procedure is n𝑛n, and the number of dropped clients is d𝑑d.
Overall the secure aggregation approach in our system leads to O​(m​n+m​d)𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑚𝑑O(mn+md) computation on the client side and O​(m​(n−d))𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑑O(m(n-d)) computation on the cloud server side.
In comparison, according to [7], their scheme leads to O​(n2+m​n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚𝑛O(n^{2}+mn) computation on the client side and O​(m​(n−d)+m​d​(n−d))𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑑𝑚𝑑𝑛𝑑O(m(n-d)+md(n-d)) on the cloud server side.
Table IV summarizes the comparison of the asymptotic computational complexity.

references:
We note that the work [7] does not present real machine learning based experiments.
To have empirical performance comparison with [7], we test their scheme111Implementation used: https://github.com/55199789/PracSecure over the MNIST model to measure the client-side and server-side runtime costs, with varying dropout rates and fraction of selected clients per around.
Table V gives the comparison of the client-side cost.
Our design is (up to 39×39\times) more efficient than the work [7] when the dropout rate is zero.
As the dropout rate increases, our design has higher client cost (limited to 2.3×2.3\times), as each online client assists by computing blinding factors scaling to the number of drop-out clients.

Regarding the server-side cost, it is observed that as the dropout rate and the fraction of selected clients increase, our design (semi-honest adv. setting) consumes less computation.
This is because the server in their scheme needs to perform reconstruction of secret keys over collected secret shares and re-compute masks to be subtracted from the aggregate sum over the online clients.
We emphasize that unlike

, our system does not reveal the secret keys of drop-out clients, so their direct participation in future rounds is not affected.
Meanwhile, our system can also provide much stronger security (computation integrity) against the server with minimal overhead, as demonstrated above.
